bioghist.p: Julien Levy (1906-1981) was a pioneering New York art dealer of the 1930s and 1940s. Levy was introduced to the art world in Paris by Marcel Duchamp, whom he had met in New York in 1926. In Paris he met photographers and artists, including Man Ray, Berenice Abbot, and Joella Haweis, daughter of Dadaist muse Mina Loy, who became his wife. Upon his return to the United States, Levy worked briefly at the Weyhe Gallery before opening the Julien Levy Gallery at 602 Madison Avenue. In 1937 he moved the gallery to 15 East 57th Street, and in 1943 he relocated again to 42 East 57th. This was the location of the gallery until it closed in 1949. In the beginning of his career, Levy exhibited and sold the work of American and European photographers, including Atget, Stieglitz, Nadar, Henri Cartier-Bresson. In 1932 Levy held the first Surrealism show in New York, displaying works from a variety of mediums, including photography, painting, sculpture, collage, and books. This show introduced major artists of the Surrealist movement, most notably Salvador Dali, whose painting “The Persistence of Memory” Levy had purchased the previous year. In addition to promoting Dali’s work, Levy was the first New York dealer to show the works of many important Surrealist-influenced artists, including Joseph Cornell, Frida Kahlo, and Arshile Gorky.

scopecontent.p: This collection of correspondence, scrapbooks, ledgers, gallery and exhibition catalogs, diaries and appointment calendars documents the work of the Julien Levy Gallery and the relationships between Julien Levy and the artists with whom he worked. The bulk of the collection consists of Levy’s correspondence with artists, other art dealers, museums, and schools, dating from 1919 to 1983. In addition to incoming and outgoing letters, the correspondence files include photographs, inventories of paintings at Levy's gallery, lists of works in shows, announcements and catalogues, and invoices and receipts. Notable correspondents include Salvador Dali, Marcel Duchamp, Man Ray, Max Ernst, Joseph Cornell, Andre Breton, Eugene Berman, Alexander Calder, Arshile Gorky, and many others. The correspondence files also include a small batch of family letters, including letters from Levy's mother Isabell Isaacs Levy to his father and Isaacs family letters from the late nineteenth century. At the end of the correspondence section are correspondence and publicity materials related to the publication of Levy’s Memoir Of An Art Gallery; inventories of the Levy Gallery; mailing lists; blueprints; stock certificates; press releases; and miscellaneous financial records 1930s-1960s. Two ledgers document the inventory at the Julien Levy Gallery from 1931 to 1961; one is a sales ledger covering the period 1942 to 1949 and the other is a ledger of individual artist’s accounts, 1940s. The collection includes a substantial number of announcements and gallery and exhibition catalogs for shows of painting, photography, and sculpture at the Julien Levy Gallery, 1932-1949. These items include materials from shows of Dali, Ernst, Gorky, Berman, Atget, Cornell, Tchelitchew, and many others. Appointment calendars, dating from 1948 to 1981 document Julien Levy’s daily activities beginning in 1948, shortly before he closed his gallery, and continuing until 1981. Two diaries that Levy kept from 1957 to 1959 offer a more personal view of his life. There is also a very brief diary kept by Jean Levy in 1957. The history of the Gallery and Julien Levy’s own range of interests can be traced through scrapbooks kept by Levy. These scrapbooks include newspaper and magazine clippings on the gallery and on artists with whom Levy worked; press releases of the Gallery; announcements and other publicity materials about the Gallery; and clippings of stories on a variety of cultural topics of interest to Levy.
